_header: Earth out of earth is wonderly wrought
Note:
Ringler Jr. (1992)
XRingler Jr., William A. Bibliography and Index of English Verse in Manuscript 1501-1558. London: Mansell, 1992; prepared and completed by Michael Rudick and Susan J. Ringler TM 377; other MSS prefix a couplet: ‘When lyf is most louyd’, etc. — see 6369. For the A-version see 6292; for the C-version see 1171; for still others see 1167 and 6293.
Subjects: mortality; transitoriness, of life; transitoriness, of world; death, approach of
Bibliographic Ghosts: Cambridge UK, Trinity College B.15.39 (181) , f. 170: see 6369
_description: ‘Erthe upon Erthe’, B-version — sixteen monorhyming quatrains

Bod220.First Lines:
ERthe oute of erthe ys wonderly wroughtErthe of erthe hath gete a
                    dignyte of nought…
Bod220.Last Lines:
…Whanne þy soule ys went out and þy body on þe erth
                    rakedThanne þy body þat was so rank and loved of all men ys
                    behated
Bod220.Editions:
Pope,  Nancy. 
             “Erthe upon Erthe Revisited.” 
             Journal of the Early Book Society
         21 (2018): 53-95: 76-8.

BodRawC307.First Lines:
Erthe opon erthe hath set all his thoghtHow that erthe opon erthe
                    may be hy broght…
BodRawC307.Last Lines:
…þat when erthe vnto erthe shall be taken tothat þe
                    saule of þis erthe suffre no wo
BodRawC307.Note:
Accompanied by Latin text, ‘Memento homo quod cinis es et in
                        cinerem reuerteris’ (f. 2)
BodRawC307.Editions:
Murray,  Hilda M. R.,
                        ed.  
             The Middle English Poem Erthe upon Erthe, printed from 24
                manuscripts.
EETS
         o.s. 141 (1911); repr. 1964.

BodSelSup53.First Lines:
Erthe apon erthe wonderly wrothErthe apon erthe hath worschyp of
                    noþch…
BodSelSup53.Last Lines:
…Now pray we god þat al erth wrowthþat erth owt of
                    erth to blys myth be browth
BodSelSup53.Editions:
Murray,  Hilda M. R.,
                        ed.  
             The Middle English Poem Erthe upon Erthe, printed from 24
                manuscripts.
EETS
         o.s. 141 (1911); repr. 1964.

OxfBal354.First Lines:
Erth owt of erth is worldly wrowghtErth hath goten oppon erth a
                    dygnite of nowght…
OxfBal354.Last Lines:
& pray to god vppon erth þat all þe erth hath
                    wrowghtÞat erth owt of erth to blis may be
                    browghtAmen
OxfBal354.Facsimiles:
Early Manuscripts at Oxford University: Facsimile

         (http://image.ox.ac.uk/show?collection=balliol&manuscript=ms354).

OxfCCC237.First Lines:
Erthe vp on erthe Is wondyrly wrowghtErthe vp on erthe getith
                    worship of nowght…
OxfCCC237.Last Lines:
…And pray god vp on erthe þat all erthe hathe wrowghtThat
                    erthe owed of þe erthe to blis may be browght
OxfCCC237.Editions:
Förster,  Max. 
             “Die älteste Fassung des mittelenglishce Gedichtes Earth Upon
                Earth.” 
             Archiv für das Studium der neueren Sprachen und
                Literaturen
         138 (1919): 39-61: 55.

CULLl510.First Lines:
Eird vpoun eird wonderfull is wrochteird hes gottin vpoun eird ane
                    dignitie for nocht…
CULLl510.Last Lines:
…And pray to god vpoun eird þat maid all of nochtThat
                    eird vpoun eird to blis may be brocht
CULLl510.Editions:
Murray,  Hilda M. R.,
                        ed.  
             The Middle English Poem Erthe upon Erthe, printed from 24
                manuscripts.
EETS
         o.s. 141 (1911); repr. 1964.

CamMagPep2553.First Lines:
Eyrd vpone eird wondirfullie is wrochtEird hes gottin vpone eird
                    ane dignite for nocht…
CamMagPep2553.Last Lines:
…And pray to god apone eird þat maid all of nochtThat
                    eird vpone eird to blys may be brocht

Murray,  Hilda M. R.,

CamTCC601.First Lines:
Erthe vppon erthe so wondyrly wroughtErthe opon erthe hath gete a
                    dignite of noghtErthe opon erthe hath set all hys thoughtHow erthe
                    apon erthe may on hyght be brought…
CamTCC601.Last Lines:
…And pray god opon erthe that all erthe hath wroughtThat erthe
                    oute of erthe to blysse may be brought
CamTCC601.Editions:
Murray,  Hilda M. R.,
                        ed.  
             The Middle English Poem Erthe upon Erthe, printed from 24
                manuscripts.
EETS
         o.s. 141 (1911); repr. 1964.

BLCottTitAXXVI.First Lines:
Erthe oute of erthe is wondirly wroghtErthe of þe erthe hathe
                    goten a dyngnyte of noght…
BLCottTitAXXVI.Last Lines:
…Lewe thy syne and lyffe in RyghtAnd than shalt thou lyffe in
                    heuyn as a knyght
BLCottTitAXXVI.Editions:
Murray,  Hilda M. R.,
                        ed.  
             The Middle English Poem Erthe upon Erthe, printed from 24
                manuscripts.
EETS
         o.s. 141 (1911); repr. 1964.

BLHar984.First Lines: How schuld erthe vpon erthe to prud & gayWhen erthe schol to erthe In so pers aray…
BLHar984.Last Lines: …and pray to god þat þe world Iroȝtþat erthe out of erthe to blesse may be broȝt
BLHar984.Note: Six lines, added to flyleaf by a later hand.

Lincoln91.First Lines:
Erthe owte of erthe es wondirly wroghteErthe hase getyn one erthe a
                    dignyte of noghteErthe appone erthe hase cett alle his thoghteHow
                    þat erthe appone erthe may be heghe broghte…
Lincoln91.Last Lines:
…ffor when þat erthe appone erthe es broghte with in
                    brynkeThane schalle erthe of erthe hafe a foulle stynke
Lincoln91.Note: Five stanzas only; nineteenth-century transcript in London,  British Library Egerton 2257, f. 100.
Lincoln91.Attributed Title:
Memento Homo Quod Cinis Es Et in cinerem Reuerteris (f. 279);

PhilUPLat33.First Lines:
Erthe oute of erth is wondyrly wroghteErthe vp on erthe gete nobley
                    of novght…
PhilUPLat33.Last Lines:
…And praye to god vpon erthe þat all the erthe
                    wrouhteÞat erthe oute of erthe to blys may be browthe
PhilUPLat33.Note:
Seven monorhyming quatrains with alternating notations
                        ‘memento’ or ‘Nosce te ipsum’ to right
                    of each; added by a fifteenth-century hand differing from that of main
                    text.

See  1170-14 above (our thanks to Nancy Pope who identifies this manuscript as Philadelphia,  University of Pennsylvania Codex 721 [olim Lat. 33; olim Harmsworth; olim Dewick; Sotheby’s Sale, Oct. 15,
               1943, Lot 2053; Raphael King, Ltd. Sale Cat. 53, No. 215, Dec. 1951]: personal communication, February 26, 2019).
